I had the worst experience with these people and here is why:

While I was working with an international company here in Ireland for almost a year, I received a job offer from Accenture Ireland, and after being selected and I signed the formal contract with them just 1 day before about to start with Accenture, from the "Onboarding team" and "HR team", telling me that I can’t start to work with them since I need to have my stamp 4 at least 6-month update in advance before the expiration date which is this December 2022. I had to say that they had this information (about my GNIB and Stamp 4 Visa) and all my legal personal information since they called me offering me the job and contract which was over 6 weeks before I was supposed to start with them.

They left me without a job as they made me sign a contract the same week that I got selected for this job offer putting me under pressure to sign the contract and asking me to give and confirm my notice of the job that I had at that moment and they left me without any jobs and the worst thing of this it's that they are not even answering any of my calls or any of my emails because I know this is not legal!

How come they can leave people like this? when we have to pay rent and bills and we depend on a job to do this, they are irresponsible with no ethics! and this is inhuman! so please, DO NOT ACCEPT ANY JOB OFFERS FROM THIS PEOPLE!

pros:
Not much work to do
Easy to pass time with useless training videos
cons:
It's a hit or miss, depending which team you get. I managed to get a scammer team. Most of the times I had to attend useless meetings, where I had to listen to half-wit people ("my childhood dream was to become a steam train... not a train driver, but a steam train"). Developers have no idea what they are doing and the management just keeps organising 100% useless meetings. It gets very tiring after a while.

The training material consist of videos for management people so that they know how to act like they know stuff about something but it's useless for programmers.

There is no scrum or jira ticketing, it's a huge mess but you are expected to do make a book keeping of your work hours. If you want to run an accounting company don't hire programmers!!!

Like every global company it has pride month and coming out days, but of course not in muslim countries - the management is a bunch of incompetent virtue signallers and you are expected to repost their garbage on LinkedIn.

The company buys a ton of useles startups and you have to be script kiddieing their messed up things all day long then convince clients to buy their scam product.

The work days is 8:30-17:30 but most people know how to act like they are working, while they are not. Everyone is fully remote, that's what makes this place bearable.

The people are pretend nice, they will backstab you and blame the failure of their useless project on you anytime.

The people in the company cheat with licensing, use trial accounts for bussiness reasons.

Avoid this company in Eastern Europe.

job_title: Transaction Processing Analyst in Manila, Manila
pros: Accenture is highly stable and seems to care at a company level. Pay is on the lower end of competitive, but the benefits are solid and won't be withdrawn capriciously. Generous training opportunities and reasonable capacity for advancement at the lower level (i.e. line processor to team lead etc).
cons:
Unfortunately your experience all depends on which project (client) you get. Accenture projects (in Accenture Operations and service delivery, at least) are run like little companies within the company, which means outside of company-wide policies your experience will depend entirely on your immediate manager and the demands of your client.

 After 6 years of a great experience with one project, inflexible management and unreasonable client demands at another burned me out in 6 months. Do your research if you're shifting projects and do your best to contact workers at your level there, and ask what the experience is like, before you transfer.

review_title: People don't resign from the company, they resign from their manager (people lead)
job_title: Solution Architect in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros: Compensation at exec level (7 and up) is competitive. The company is generous in training certifications, and during pandemic, they gave significant amount of allowance for their employees work from home setup. There are many events to bring people together.
cons:
1. HMO issues - HMO for dependents have contestability period. It's 2 years for parents, and 1 year for kids. Contestability period is when you cannot use the 100% coverage until you have satisfied the contestability period. Also, the HMO contribution for dependents is not 100% shouldered by company. It's subsidized only. Other companies in the Philippines (as big as them) cover 100% of contribution without contestability period.


2. Unskilled People Managers/Leads - In big organizations like this, you often encounter good and poor people management skills. But I have reason to believe there are many of the poorly-skilled ones than the good ones here. The people managers/lead don't really undertake behavior qualifications nor pass certain workshops on how to be a people manager. They are promoted based on tasks achievements or when the business have grown, but they lack experience & knowledge in proper people handling. There is just too many error.. some you can use as ground for labor complaint in DOLE. 


3. Accenture is a PEZA company so they are required to use the PEZE locations, if not they will pay.. so they require their employees to sit in the office 1x-2x per week in the office.

4. Not as multi-cultural as I expected - There is only Filipino and Indian culture. So imagine that combination, e.g. blind appeal to authority, men underestimating women, culture of saving face, etc. There are many politics-savvy in this company and the leaders thrive here, haha!

5. Careful in recruitment! - Recruitment they low ball every candidate. They would even offer you lower salary than your current. They did that to my referral. The remedy here is tell the hiring manager during their interview how much you want. Also it's a 10-hour work day here and the dependent HMO contestability period are the items they will not tell you until you sign the contract.

review_title: Typical Big 4 - Profit driven, lacking a mission and culture
pros:
- Big brand to have on your CV
- A lot of opportunities with big brands/clients (if you have experience and leverage)
cons:
- Accenture cut costs at every corner. The standard issue Dell laptop provided barely holds a charge for 1 hour and overheats when you power it up. They give you a wired mouse and a terrible backpack in the welcome package.

- Training at Accenture is a joke. Training programs are poorly run with terrible logistics, it's impossible to find the content you need to learn for a specific qualification. Accenture push everyone towards their free learning library, even though it SUCKS. There is no opportunity to get paid training, even if you are an experienced hire and it makes sense for your department to invest in specialised talent, that would both benefit the client and other consultants.

- Culture at Accenture is ZERO. Their idea of culture is to host as many meetings as possible to force more information to you (service offerings, capability building), even when COVID/Zoom burnout is real.
Leadership at Accenture are delusional, thinking Microsoft Team message threads are a way to build team culture.
Accenture hold onto every single dollar, not willing to invest in small team building, or larger team gatherings. They'll use COVID safety as a cover up, which is a BS excuse since companies with great culture have started small group gatherings (provided individuals are vaccinated).

review_title: Crap don’t join Accenture operations financial services
pros: You will have several trackers to work on. Nothing interesting to work
cons: Leaders have no knowledge in driving transformation. They spend most of their time reviewing trackers, applying filters, creating one sliders for the improvement done a decade back. They lack understanding of basic concepts of transformation. Lot of caste, religion l, geo based divisions. Speech like there was time a specific geo dominated, now dominated by another geo people from India. These are all common. Transformation rigour is missing. To push that another set of people recruited and a program called as back to basic is being run. Funny people. People will search for complex methods like analytics modelling without even getting into the process and understanding why it is caused. Mass resignation happened among manager level and above in one of the team. Leaders there think that banking is something special and only few people could understand banking. Such funny beliefs are still there.

review_title: Great Benefits, but almost toxic work culture
pros:
Great benefits and opportunities to move around the company and try different roles.

You can find some absolute gems of human beings when you look hard enough. I wouldn't still be there without them.
cons:
The work culture is very competitive and there is strong focus on career progression. In my opinion from what I've seen, this is often to the detriment of quality work that is compromised by ambitious people focused only on the end goal (their promotion).

There is also a disparity between the goals and values that Accenture lay out in their Business Ethics training and their employees conduct in practice. This training is a very jarring hour when it forces one to recollect instances of colleagues who do not live out these values. For instance, on Mental Health and, sadly, harassment.

-QA has quotas for giving out negative reviews, end of month is brutal if you aren't popular.

-Genuine willingness to help is punished. I was fired for pointing out autopopulate on an excel sheet would save the company thousands of man hours per year.

-IT security is extremely lax, any business with a "marketing expert" from Facebook should consider all of their data compromised

-Company name, salary, hours, position, and benefits are blatantly misrepresented during hiring process. All 30 people hired in my "batch" were blindsided by the change

-Employee support exists but is more negative than positive. Expect to be ordered to call the same 10-20 people 30+ times a day and harassed when they don't answer

-paid training consists exclusively of Facebook brand training, Facebook security protocols you'll be instructed to violate and praising upper management and how "you can move up quick if you try really hard"

-Multiple teams chats where all employees are required to post every successful call, dozens of emails per day about various contests with no information how to participate, and the same handful of people winning said contests every day
